block.p: Dr. Karen Elizabeth Lasser, a daughter of Dr. Joan L. Lasser of Providence, R.I., and Dr. Abraham Lasser of Pawtucket, R.I., was married last evening to Maxim D. Shrayer, the son of Emilia Shrayer and Dr. David Shrayer, also of Providence. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman performed the ceremony there in Manning Chapel at Brown University.

Dr. Lasser, who is 31 and is keeping her name, received her medical degree from Cornell University. She is a fellow in general medicine at Cambridge Hospital in Massachusetts, where she does epidemiological research, and a primary care physician at the Somerville Primary Care Center, a neighborhood health clinic in Somerville, Mass. She graduated from Harvard, where she is also working on a master's degree in public health.

Dr. Lasser, who is 31 and is keeping her name, received her medical degree from Cornell University. She is a fellow in general medicine at Cambridge Hospital in Massachusetts, where she does epidemiological research, and a primary care physician at the Somerville Primary Care Center, a neighborhood health clinic in Somerville, Mass. She graduated from Harvard, where she is also working on a master's degree in public health.
Her father, a retired surgical pathologist, worked at Miriam Hospital in Providence. Her mother is a staff radiologist at Rhode Island Medical Imaging, a group practice in Warwick.

Mr. Shrayer, 33, is an assistant professor of Russian literature at Boston College and the author of ''Russian Poet/Soviet Jew'' (Rowman & Littlefield, 2000) and other works. He graduated from Brown and received a master's degree in comparative literature from Rutgers and a Ph.D. in Russian literature from Yale.

His mother is a cataloger at the Rockefeller Library at Brown and a freelance translator and interpreter. His father is an assistant research professor of surgery at the medical schools of Brown and Boston University, where he does research in experimental oncology.
